pullRequest.body:
Main definitions

- `pNilradical`: the `p`-nilradical of a ring is an ideal consists of elements `x` such that
  `x ^ p ^ n = 0` for some `n` (`mem_pNilradical`). It is equal to the nilradical if `p > 1`
  (`pNilradical_eq_nilradical`), otherwise it is equal to zero (`pNilradical_eq_bot`).

- `IsPRadical`: a ring homomorphism `i : K →+* L` of characteristic `p` rings is called `p`-radical,
  if or any element `x` of `L` there is `n : ℕ` such that `x ^ (p ^ n)` is contained in `K`,
  and the kernel of `i` is contained in the `p`-nilradical of `K`.
  A generalization of purely inseparable extension for fields.

- `IsPerfectClosure`: a ring homomorphism `i : K →+* L` of characteristic `p` rings makes `L` a
  perfect closure of `K`, if `L` is perfect, and `i` is `p`-radical.

- `PerfectRing.lift`: if a `p`-radical ring homomorphism `K →+* L` is given, `M` is a perfect ring,
  then any ring homomorphism `K →+* M` can be lifted to `L →+* M`.
  This is similar to `IsAlgClosed.lift` and `IsSepClosed.lift`.

- `PerfectRing.liftEquiv`: `K →+* M` is one-to-one correspondence to `L →+* M`,
  given by `PerfectRing.lift`. This is a generalization to `PerfectClosure.lift`.

- `IsPerfectClosure.equiv`: perfect closures of a ring are isomorphic.

Main results

- `IsPRadical.trans`: composition of `p`-radical ring homomorphisms is also `p`-radical.

- `PerfectClosure.isPerfectClosure`: the absolute perfect closure `PerfectClosure` is a
  perfect closure.

- `IsPRadical.isPurelyInseparable`, `IsPurelyInseparable.isPRadical`: `p`-radical and
  purely inseparable are equivalent for fields.

- `perfectClosure.isPerfectClosure`: the (relative) perfect closure `perfectClosure` is a
  perfect closure.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go

using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

- [x] depends on: #8860

The works about separable degree and separable closure were already split as other PRs:

- [x] depends on: #9041 [part one]

~~... and does not depend on: #9488 [part three: purely inseparable]~~

By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

> In order to ease automation, this should be a simp lemma

I marked quite a lot of results as simp lemmas. Not sure if they are too many.

Thanks for this contribution!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8247758427/job/22556611466)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8247758427/job/22556610563)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8247758427/job/22556610985)

I think most of the above lemmas are **not** needed if you use [iterateFrobeniusEquiv](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/Perfect.html#iterateFrobeniusEquiv) I just introduced in #10016, which is already a RingEquiv. I also added [two more lemmas](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/9311/files#diff-e161d5e9d8af730e6a06bd5fb3f86e514a748447e287d2c2c9e9a2e95ee0769eR90-R96) in #9311.
Is it a good idea to introduce `iterateFrobeniusEquivSymm`?
Would you not define it as `(iterateFrobeniusEquiv R p n).symm`?
You could add a version that assumes `Nat.Prime p` and another for `pNilradical R 1 = ⊥`, to parallel the two cases of ExpChar.
Please try to migrate to `iterateFrobeniusEquiv`

Your snippet on Zulip uses `[perfectRing' : PerfectRing L p]`, why not here? Then this line wouldn't be needed, right?
```suggestion
```
I assume that `[perfectRing' : PerfectRing L p]` will give you an `instance IsPerfectClosure.perfectRing'`, right? But this will not quite work if I understand correctly.
Does it really give the instance, and what do you mean by "not quite work"? I think `extends` will give the instance, [] should just auto-fill the instance by typeclass inference.

> Does it really give the instance, and what do you mean by "not quite work"?

I mean `instance IsPerfectClosure.perfectRing` will not work because LHS has more free variables than RHS. Only `theorem IsPerfectClosure.perfectRing` works.

> [] should just auto-fill the instance by typeclass inference.

That's good to know, which is exactly what I wanted.

```suggestion
`i` is "purely inseparable", the kernel of `i` is contained in the `p`-nilradical of `K`, and `M` is
a perfect ring, then `PerfectRing.liftAux` is a ring homomorphism. -/
```
I think these should be replaced by `IsPerfectClosure`
But these three conditions are for different rings. If they are for the same ring, then it's `IsPerfectClosure`.

I see! It's similar to [IsSepClosed.lift](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/IsSepClosed.html#IsSepClosed.lift), [IsAlgClosed.lift](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/IsAlgClosed/Basic.html#IsAlgClosed.lift) etc. (PerfectRing is like IsPurelyInseparbleClosed) but enjoys uniqueness.

Even though we could redefine [PerfectClosure.lift](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/PerfectClosure.html#PerfectClosure.lift) using this but it won't be as nice definitionally as it is now. The noncomputability of the current PerfectClosure.lift is all contained within `frobeniusEquiv`, while here `liftAux` uses choice to pick an `n`. If we change
```
pow_mem' : ∀ x : L, ∃ (n : ℕ) (y : K), i y = x ^ p ^ n
```
to 
```
pow_mem' : (x : L) → trunc {ny : ℕ × K // i ny.2 = x ^ p ^ ny.1}
```
then we can make PerfectRing.lift definitionally as nice as PerfectClosure.lift, but I think it's overly complicated for little gain, so I'd suggest just leave PerfectClosure.lift as is.
~~This `PerfectRing.lift` is not the same as the `PerfectClosure.lift`. I'm not defining `IsPerfectClosure.lift` yet, will do it later.~~
~~I think that the original `PerfectClosure.lift` is a special case of `IsPRadical.lift`~~, here `IsPRadical` is a generalization of `IsPurelyInseparable` to rings.
Ohhhh I think you're right. I added `IsPRadical` and `PerfectRing.liftEquiv` which is indeed a generalization of `PerfectClosure.lift`.

Currently `PerfectRing + IsPRadical => IsPerfectClosure` and `IsPerfectClosure => IsPRadical` can be inferred automatically, but not `IsPerfectClosure => PerfectRing` as an instance. This annoys me a little bit.

I have an idea that we should not talk about the compound `IsPerfectClosure`, but talk about `PerfectRing + IsPRadical` everywhere, which avoids the above problem. Any opinions?

That would be at odds with the design of IsAlgClosure, IsSepClosure etc. and the bundled versions may have performance benefits (found faster in instance search), but I think it's good to experiment with alternative designs!
Oh, the same problem also occurred for `IsAlgClosure`, and `IsSepClosure`. Perhaps I should not change it for `IsPerfectClosure`.
I don't know where to put these results into. The `IntermediateField` file doesn't import things about characteristic.
Have you tried `find_home`? You can at worst create a new file.
`find_home` suggests `Mathlib` if I remembered correctly. Is it a good idea to create a new file `Algebra/CharP/IntermediateField`?
I don't see any reason to not do so.

```suggestion
- `pNilradical`: the `p`-nilradical of a ring is an ideal consisting of elements `x` such that
```
Also the phrasing here and the docstring of `pNilradical` should be clarified to better take into account the cases `1 < p` or not.
I would think it would be a better design not to make `IsPerfectClose.mk` an instance.
Is it better to use `extends`? Then I think you automatically get the instance.

> Is it better to use `extends`? Then I think you automatically get the instance.

Let me try `extends` later.

I think the best solution is to do this:
```suggestion
abbrev IsPerfectClosure [PerfectRing L p] := IsPRadical i p
```
Then, the annoying `haveI := perfectRing ...` below would no longer be needed.
Can you explain this code a little bit? I don't understand `abbrev` followed with `[...]`.

Having `[PerfectRing L p]` makes it necessary that we know `[PerfectRing L p]` holds before we may even state `IsPerfectClosure i p`. Then, assuming `[PerfectRing L p]`, `IsPerfectClosure i p` and `IsPRadical i p` become completely synonymous (and this is transparent: the lemmas that you have shown under the assumption `IsPRadical i p` will automatically hold if `IsPerfectClosure i p` is known).

(It is possible that the linter complains that the variable `[PerfectRing L p]` is not used in this declaration, but we may circumvent this by using `@[nolint unusedArguments]`.)

No, this does not work... it immediately complains about `failed to synthesize instance PerfectRing L p` in next theorem `IsPerfectClosure.perfectRing`

I think your suggestion is basically the same as in https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/8696#discussion_r1485089490, but then I decided to not use it some time ago...

> No, this does not work... it immediately complains about failed to synthesize instance PerfectRing L p in next theorem IsPerfectClosure.perfectRing

Of course, it has to fail: the point is whenever you need to write `IsPerfectClosure`, you need to assume `PerfectRing` also. The point of using an abbreviation (and then use `PerfectRing` + `IsPerfectClosure`) is that it has a certain aesthetic advantage over `PerfectRing` + `IsPRadical`.
Oh I see. Then it is exactly what I was proposed before. In fact I have no preferences between these two approaches. Let's ask some more people.

In order to ease automation, this should be a simp lemma:
```suggestion
@[simp]
theorem PerfectRing.lift_comp_apply (x : K) : lift i j p (i x) = j x := by
  rw [lift_apply i j p _ 0 x (by rw [pow_zero, pow_one]), iterateFrobeniusEquiv_zero]; rfl
```

After this definition, you should add the following lemma (not sure it is the best name though):
```lean
lemma RingHom.ext_of_perfectRing
    {φ₁ φ₂ : L →+* M} (h : φ₁.comp i = φ₂.comp i) : φ₁ = φ₂ :=
  (PerfectRing.liftEquiv M i p).symm.injective h
```
Then, using the simp lemma `lift_comp_apply`, some proofs should be facilitated, like:
```lean
theorem PerfectRing.lift_comp_lift [PerfectRing N p] [IsPRadical j p] :
    (lift j k p).comp (lift i j p) = lift i k p :=
  RingHom.ext_of_perfectRing i p (by ext; simp)
```

I think your `RingHom.ext_of_perfectRing` is closely related to [IsPurelyInseparable.injective_comp_algebraMap](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/PurelyInseparable.html#IsPurelyInseparable.injective_comp_algebraMap). Let me study if a `IsPRadical.injective_comp` should be added.
Thanks for the suggestion. But I only spot `PerfectRing.lift_comp_lift` which can be benefitted by this result. Are there any other?

`injective_comp_of_perfect` is essentially a universal property: it should be useful to obtain equalities involving morphisms to perfect rings obtained with `lift`. Rather than redoing multiple times the argument consisting of writing elements as a `p^?`-powers, the idea would be to prove first lemmas stating an equality of `RingHom` by using `IsPRadical.injective_comp_of_perfect` to reduce to an equality involving elements coming from the "smallest ring", and then deduce the `_apply` version.

I would suggest removing the lemmas `liftAux_id_apply`, `liftAux_id`, `liftAux_self_apply` and `liftAux_self` lemmas. Then, after the definition of `PerfectRing.lift` and of the lemma `lift_apply`, you may immediately prove the very critical lemma `PerfectRing.lift_comp_apply`. Then, for example, some lemmas become:
```lean
@[simp]
theorem PerfectRing.lift_self [PerfectRing L p] : lift i i p = RingHom.id L :=
  IsPRadical.injective_comp_of_perfect _ i p (by ext; simp)

@[simp]
theorem PerfectRing.lift_id : lift (RingHom.id K) j p = j :=
  IsPRadical.injective_comp_of_perfect _ (RingHom.id K) p (by
    ext x
    exact PerfectRing.lift_comp_apply (RingHom.id K) j p x)

@[simp]
theorem PerfectRing.comp_lift : lift i (f.comp i) p = f :=
  IsPRadical.injective_comp_of_perfect _ i p (by ext; simp)
```

It is likely that some other lemmas could be obtained in a similar way.

Also, as there are many definitions in `PerfectRing` namespace, so that you may consider using the syntax `namespace PerfectRing`.

Some lemmas about `liftAux` you mentioned only requires `CommSemiring`, however `IsPRadical.injective_comp_of_perfect` requires `CommRing`. So personally I don't want to remove them. Ohterwise I think your suggestion is good.
I spotted another lemma `lift_lift` which can be golfed.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(FieldTheory/IsPerfectClosure): predicate `IsPerfectClosure`

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(FieldTheory/SeparableDegree): further properties of separable degree of fields and polynomials
